summary: This document is a deposition transcript where a witness, likely a former U.S. Attorney, is questioned about the negotiation and review process of the Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein. The testimony covers internal DOJ communications, concerns about the NPA's treatment of victims, a controversial breakfast meeting with defense counsel, and post-agreement legal considerations regarding potential breach. This document is a deposition transcript where Alexander Acosta, former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, is questioned about his office's handling of the Jeffrey Epstein case. The questioning focuses on whether Acosta invited or supported reviews by the Department of Justice's Criminal Division and the Office of the Deputy Attorney General (ODAG) of the non-prosecution agreement (NPA) with Epstein, following defense counsel's appeals. Acosta discusses his communications with defense attorneys, his perspective on the review process, and his interpretation of the scope of the DOJ's review of the NPA. This document is a deposition transcript where a U.S. Attorney is questioned about the decision-making process regarding victim notifications in the Jeffrey Epstein case. The questioning focuses on correspondence between the U.S. Attorney's Office and defense attorneys about whether and how to notify victims of Epstein's pending state plea agreement in 2007, and the office's interpretation of its obligations under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA). This document is a deposition transcript of a witness (likely former U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta) being questioned about the 2008 non-prosecution agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein. The questioning focuses on victim notification procedures, communication between federal and state prosecutors, the decision-making process around the NPA, and interactions with Epstein's defense team. This document is a deposition transcript where a former U.S. Attorney (the witness) is questioned about the handling of the Jeffrey Epstein case. The questioning focuses on the level of access granted to Epstein's high-profile defense attorneys, media coverage of the case, allegations of improper influence, and the aggressive tactics employed by the defense team. The witness defends the office's actions, stating they held firm to their positions despite pressure. This document is a transcript of a deposition or interview with Alexander Acosta, former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, conducted by the Department of Justice's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR). Acosta is questioned about his office's handling of the Jeffrey Epstein non-prosecution agreement (NPA), victim notification, Epstein's work release, sex offender registration, and missing email records from his tenure.

events.title: Breakfast Meeting with Defense Counsel
events.description: The witness had a one-on-one breakfast meeting with defense attorney Jay Lefkowitz. The witness states the NPA was already signed, but the meeting raised public concerns about negotiating pending open issues.

events.title: Lefkowitz's Letter Recounting Breakfast
events.description: Jay Lefkowitz sent a letter to the witness recounting his version of the October 12 breakfast meeting, claiming the office promised not to intervene with the state or contact claimants.

events.title: Witness's Rebuttal Letter Drafted
events.description: The witness drafted/edited a firm response to Lefkowitz's October 23 letter, clarifying that the office 'cannot and will not agree' to the promises Lefkowitz claimed were made, effectively rejecting his characterization.

events.title: Witness's Letter to Ken Starr
events.description: The witness wrote a letter to Ken Starr in response to the issue Starr raised about the NPA's victim representation scheme (22.55).

events.title: Acosta Letter to Ken Starr
events.description: Alexander Acosta writes a letter to defense attorney Ken Starr in response to Starr's letter raising issues about the Epstein agreement, expressing frustration with continued challenges and stating the office is ready to proceed to trial if necessary.

events.title: Defense Counsel Meeting with Acosta
events.description: Defense counsel meets with Alexander Acosta and informs him they will go to the Department of Justice's Criminal Division to seek a review of the Epstein case.

events.title: ODAG Letter to Defense Counsel
events.description: The Office of the Deputy Attorney General sends a letter to defense attorneys Jay Lefkowitz and Ken Starr stating they have completed a thorough review of the U.S. Attorney's handling of the Epstein matter and see no reason to intervene.

events.title: Initial Meeting in Miami
events.description: Acosta's office invites Department of Justice officials to Miami for an initial meeting on the Epstein case, anticipating the matter would eventually be reviewed in Washington.

events.title: State Plea Agreement Notification
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office considers notifying victims about Epstein's upcoming state plea agreement, as referenced in document 32b.

events.title: Decision on Victim Notification
events.description: The U.S. Attorney sends a letter (Exhibit 41b) agreeing not to notify victims of the state plea and instead having the state be responsible for that notification, while the federal office would notify victims of the federal resolution.

events.title: Scheduled State Plea Hearing
events.description: A state plea and sentencing for Epstein was initially scheduled for this date, as referenced in a draft victim notification letter. The plea was later postponed.

events.title: Starr Complaint Letter
events.description: Defense attorney Ken Starr writes to the U.S. Attorney complaining about an oral victim notification given by an AUSA and stating the defense thought the notification process was on hold.

events.title: Scheduled Epstein Plea Date
events.description: The date scheduled for Jeffrey Epstein's change of plea in state court, which was later delayed.

events.title: Epstein's State Court Guilty Plea
events.description: The date Jeffrey Epstein ultimately pled guilty in state court, as referenced in a victim notification letter drafted beforehand.

events.title: Acosta's Letter on Victim Notification
events.description: Date of a letter from Alexander Acosta discussed in the deposition, which addressed victim notification procedures and the tie between the federal resolution and state plea.

events.title: Notification of Impending Plea
events.description: On a Friday afternoon, AUSA Villafaña received a copy of Epstein's proposed state plea agreement and learned the change of plea was scheduled for the following Monday, prompting attempts to notify victims.

events.title: Defense Attorneys' Meeting with U.S. Attorney
events.description: Epstein's defense attorneys requested and were granted a meeting with the U.S. Attorney before the Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) was signed.

events.title: Post-NPA Communications and Reprimands
events.description: After the NPA was signed, defense attorney Jay Lefkowitz repeatedly contacted the U.S. Attorney directly, leading to the U.S. Attorney reprimanding him and instructing him to communicate through line attorneys.

events.title: Defense Investigation of Prosecutors
events.description: The defense team investigated individual prosecutors and their families, looking for 'personal peccadillos,' and attempted to disqualify two prosecutors.

events.title: Threat of Book on Prosecutorial Overreach
events.description: Professor Alan Dershowitz threatened that the U.S. Attorney would be the subject of a chapter in a book on prosecutorial overreach if they continued to pursue the matter.

events.title: Missing Email Records Gap
events.description: A portion of Alexander Acosta's email account as U.S. Attorney, containing emails received between May 26, 2007, and March 2008, could not be recovered by the Department of Justice despite record retention requirements.

events.title: Acosta Press Conference
events.description: Alexander Acosta held a press conference where he referenced victims' horrific experiences and stated he had seen videos and interviews of victims recently, not from 2006-2007.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) Discussions
events.description: Extensive discussions about the NPA with Epstein, including concerns about victim notification, work release, sex offender registration, and keeping the agreement confidential.

keyFacts: A high-level DOJ official (the witness) testified that defense attorney Jay Lefkowitz repeatedly and inaccurately recharacterized their conversations regarding the Epstein NPA.
The witness had a controversial one-on-one breakfast meeting with Epstein's attorney, Jay Lefkowitz, shortly after the NPA was signed, which raised optical concerns about negotiating pending issues.

Internal criticism of the NPA was raised, noting Epstein was getting a 'much better deal than the average defendant' and that the terms were 'advantageous for the defendant, and not all that helpful to the victims.'

The witness expressed significant post-agreement concern that if the office walked away from the signed NPA, they would face difficult litigation over whether a breach occurred, which informed their decision to grant process and delay.
A key issue in the NPA was the '22.55' scheme for victim representation, which was appealed to main Justice (CEOS) after Ken Starr raised concerns about it.
Alexander Acosta states he did not 'invite' the Department of Justice reviews of the Epstein non-prosecution agreement but did not oppose them, believing defense counsel had a right to seek review.

Acosta wrote a letter to defense attorney Ken Starr on December 4, 2007, pushing back on new issues raised and indicating his office was ready to unwind the agreement and proceed to trial if necessary.

The Office of the Deputy Attorney General, in a June 23, 2008 letter, stated it reviewed the U.S. Attorney's 'handling' of the Epstein matter and found no reason to intervene, but did not explicitly state it reviewed or approved the non-prosecution agreement itself.
Acosta acknowledges the review process delayed the Epstein case and that the case 'did not get better with time,' as witnesses aged.

Defense counsel raised issues about the legality and ethics of the non-prosecution agreement, including whether it was an abuse of discretion or used federal criminal law to extract civil concessions.

The U.S. Attorney's Office extended the 'courtesy' to Epstein's defense team to review draft letters intended to notify victims of the pending state plea agreement, a practice the witness stated was unusual and the first time it had risen to management level.

The office ultimately decided (in a Dec. 19, 2007 letter) that the state attorney's office would be responsible for notifying victims of the state plea resolution, while the federal office would notify victims of the federal case resolution.

A key concern cited for carefully managing victim notifications was the potential for the defense to use knowledge of the plea agreement to impeach victim-witnesses at a future trial (e.g., by suggesting their testimony was influenced by potential restitution).

The U.S. Attorney recalled the office's legal view was that the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) did not legally require notification in this specific circumstance because the case had not been indicted, making notification discretionary rather than mandatory.
Draft victim notification letters were prepared and addressed but were never sent after the scheduled December 14, 2007 plea was postponed and after defense pushback.

The witness (Acosta) defends the victim notification process, stating the federal resolution of the case was tied to the state plea and that victims were to be notified of the state hearing where the federal matter would be terminated.
Acosta references significant frustration within the prosecution team, including emails suggesting "why don't we just rip this up?" regarding the NPA, due to Epstein's conduct and delays.

Acosta states that victim notification letters were halted at one point because prosecutors concluded Epstein might not honor the NPA, and they feared defense would claim victims were encouraged to overstate claims for monetary compensation.
The witness acknowledges that once the NPA was signed, the U.S. couldn't unwind it simply because victims disliked it or prosecutors were frustrated, absent legal invalidity.

Acosta responds to criticism about defense team access by arguing that despite their efforts and appeals, the prosecution's core demands (jail time, registration, restitution) did not change over a year of negotiations.
The witness, a former U.S. Attorney, states that Epstein's defense team was 'more aggressive than any' they had previously encountered, investigating prosecutors and their families.
The witness defends granting a meeting to Epstein's high-profile defense attorneys before the NPA was signed, stating it was not atypical for a case nearing resolution.

The witness claims media coverage has been inaccurate, particularly in portraying the case as an international conspiracy involving figures like Prince Andrew, rather than focusing on the local Palm Beach incidents.
The witness denies ever being offered any payments, favors, or job assistance in connection with the Epstein case, and states they have no knowledge of such offers to anyone in their office.

The witness wrote a 'to whom it may concern' letter to journalist Julie K. Brown to defend the office's actions, stating that despite the 'army' of powerful defense attorneys, the office held firm to its original terms.

Alexander Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, expected Jeffrey Epstein to be treated like a typical offender and did not expect him to receive work release, aligning with the state attorney's office's efforts to prevent it.
Acosta stated he was never made aware that Jeffrey Epstein was an intelligence asset and denied that defense counsel ever claimed Epstein had that status.

A significant gap exists in the DOJ's electronic records: emails received by Acosta between May 26, 2007, and March 2008 were not recovered, despite legal requirements to maintain U.S. Attorney records indefinitely.
Acosta took ultimate responsibility for his office's handling of the Epstein case, stating that as U.S. Attorney, criticisms should fall on him, not just his senior managers.
Acosta acknowledged that if the lengthy, uncertain period of the NPA negotiations had been foreseen, his office might have handled victim notification very differently.
